etymology.description: Uncertain; Shuowen: inverted 之 (originally 㞢); Zhang Shichao: “roots” 柢; oracle bones: 之 represents a footprint.
etymology.interpretation: Scholars propose several origins: an inversion of 之, an image of spreading roots, or a footprint mark. Each points to motion or extension around something, which aligns with the sense of circling or surrounding.

examples.chinese: 敌军帀城而围之(敵軍帀城而圍之)。
examples.pinyin: Díjūn zā chéng ér wéi zhī.
examples.english: The enemy army went around the city and laid siege to it.

examples.chinese: 商人帀市叫卖(商人帀市叫賣)。
examples.english: Merchants went around the market hawking their goods.

examples.chinese: 我们沿湖帀行一圈(我們沿湖帀行一圈)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒmen yán hú zā xíng yī quān.
examples.english: We went around the lake for one lap.
